content:
Edited to improve the formatting (set examples in monospace areas, remove the excessive use of bold, + a few other details).

It might be worth mentioning that when both letters of a pair are the same, rule 1 is the one to apply (it follows logically from the statement, as rules are applied in the given order, BUT it's not the usual rule for this case in the "classical" playfair cipher, see wikipedia for instance).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good for learning basic data structures and 2D array manipulations.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Oh c'mon it's ok puzzle.

Good topic, but there are sadly some important things that need to be fixed before approval.

Parameter W is useless if it is always 5. Should be removed and stated as a constant  
Row testcase should be the same as example in text.
The first row and column test also the same as in the provided example.
The order of tests should be different - starting with row-ones, as the second column test actually requires the valid implementation of the row rule

There are too many things that are not stated in the statement nor given in examples:
- including how to treat lower case letters (are they in key table or not?)
- "letters to their immediate right" actually can be not immediate right as we go around and modulo.


Definitely it shouldn't be posted as an easy task. (Existence of more difficult easy puzzles is not an argument to make more such misjudged entries.)
This puzzle is definitely too long and laborious for this. ENCRYPT would be enough for the puzzle to work - but that's not a critical point just an observation.
All your test cases use the same key table. I believe they should be different.
Still working on the test cases, :) but will change them before approval.

Hey! Thank you for the feedback :) 

I altered my submission as you suggested as well as added an example for the edge cases. Can you confirm if the provided example is understandable?

I will definitely think about the difficulty level with how much labor is put into solving it from next time. Any other changes I should make for this?

Thank you for the edits, really appreciate it. :)

It is true that usually, the letter that isn't used replaces the repeated letter, but I tried to bend the rules a little for this puzzle. Umm, I will mention the rule changes tho.

I will work on this puzzle later today and continue the revision. As for now just a slight suggestion that in the input lines 1-5 description maybe add that the row length is always 5 also.

Considering "hardness" - it is always very different when solving your own puzzle, comparing to other's when you do not know their intentions and it is much easier to misunderstood some things and spend hours working on some unclear detail.

Thanks, I updated with the changes. Although I did notice that I have already mentioned the key table as 5 X 5 grid beforehand in the description.

I do know this feeling of not understanding what the creator wants to communicate, while I was trying to solve "ENIGMA - 3 ROTORS WITHOUT PLUGBOARD". The example was really confusing, so I still haven't solved it yet. Will keep this feeling in mind.

Yes you're right - it might be that the phrase at the beginning is enough. I didn't remember it.

OK, I finally did it - it is OK - I approve.
Thanks a lot :). Now for the final approval.
Hey, I think I am done. Do you have any other improvements for this puzzle? I would love to get your feedback again.
Nice, I like it! But I have one more question. Why do you provide dimensions of key table in input if they do not change (5x5)?
I was thinking about a version two with varying dimensions. But no particular reason, so I changed it. Hmm, anything else?
Umm, I was wondering if the puzzle level is under? Or is it just right?
I think the puzzle level is right, because there are puzzles in 'Easy' section that are more difficult than this.
Noted.  Btw how do I get approvals for this now?
